repnme.cdata!:
Progress report on implementation of
            management recommendations and action plan Yacyreta

abstracts.cdata!:
Yacyreta is a multibillion US dollar
            hydroelectric facility on the Parana River, along the border
            between Argentina and Paraguay.  Consistent with the
            Board's guidance, this report provides updates on: (a)
            implementation of the Bank's Action Plan and additional
            measures identified by Management with respect to the
            affected parties; (b) grievance procedures for resolving
            claims related to the project; (c) project activities
            supported by the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB), and
            IDB-Bank collaboration on issues identified in the
            investigation; and (d) decisions taken with respect to the
            reservoir's water level and potential impacts. Annex 1
            provides a more detailed presentation of implementation
            progress on each of the issues covered in the Management
            Action Plan.

            Paraguay Reform For The Water And Telecommunications Sectors

abstracts.cdata!:
On May 30, 2002, the Inspection Panel
            registered a Request for Inspection concerning the Project,
            linked to Loans 3520-AR and 3842-PA and subsequently
            conducted a full Inspection o f the Project.  On May 6, 2004
            the Board Executive Directors discussed and approved the
            Management Response to the Inspection Panel's in-depth
            study.' The Board also asked for follow-up reporting. A
            90-day Progress Report was issued on August 6, 2004. The
            Management Response and Recommendation also envisaged
            subsequent annual reports. This report constitutes the first
            such annual report and covers the period August 2004 -mid-
            September 2005. This report includes updates in the
            following areas: (a) implementation o f the Bank's
            Action Plan and additional measures identified by Management
            with respect to the affected parties (including the 2,416
            families already relocated and the estimated 6,000 families
            to be relocated in Paraguay prior to completion o f the
            Project); (b) grievance procedures for resolving claims
            related to the Project; (c) the activities o f the
            Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) in the Project, and
            how the IDB and the Bank have been collaborating on issues
            identified during the Inspection; and (d) decisions taken
            with respect to the reservoir's water level and
            potential impacts. Annex 1 provides a datasheet on the
            Project; and Annex 2 provides a more detailed presentation o
            f implementation progress on the key issues covered in the
            Management Action Plan.

repnme.cdata!: Argentina - Fifth SEGBA power Distribution Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the SEGBA Power
            Distribution Project for Argentina were as follows: the
            outcome was unsatisfactory, the sustainability was likely,
            the institutional development impact was modest, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both unsatisfactory. The
            lessons learned indicate that an implementing agency must be
            accountable to some form of governing body and have a clear
            and transparent organizational structure. Local institutions
            need to play major role in the decision-making process and
            in implementing relevant mitigatory measures. Environmental
            management plans, and more importantly resettlement plans,
            need to be considered an investment priority and implemented
            in coordination with the construction phase of the main
            civil works in order to mitigate potential future conflicts.
            The complexity and management commitment required to manage
            Involuntary Resettlement is often underestimated.
            Environmental management and resettlement/rehabilitation
            plans should be immediately updated when unforeseen delays
            and situations arise. Siting of hydroelectric dams is the
            single most important decision shaping environmental and
            social issues. A good communications program is critical.
            Due to a lack of sufficient baseline information, Yacyreta
            Binational Entity (EBY) has repeatedly been unable to
            respond properly to claims as they arise, which has resulted
            in increased social conflicts. Land acquisition and
            resettlement must be linked. Phased resettlement, in
            addition to adding costs, also incurs greater social disruption.

repnme.cdata!:
Paraguay Reform Project for the Water and
            Telecommunications Sectors and the Argentina SEGBA V Power
            Distribution Project : progress report on implementation of
            the Management Recommendations and Action Plan

abstracts.cdata!:
On May 6, 2004, the Executive Directors
            of the World Bank discussed the Inspection Panel Report,
            "Paraguay: Reform Project for the Water and
            Telecommunication Sectors and Argentina: SEGBA V Power
            Distribution Project" (dated February 24, 2004), as
            well as the "Management Report and Recommendations in
            Response to the Inspection Panel Investigation Report"
            (dated April 6, 2004). During the Board meeting, the
            Executive Directors approved the Management Action Plan and
            requested that Management investigate additional measures to
            address the issues identified by the Panel and report to the
            Board in 90 days on progress made. The Board requested that
            the Report include progress and updates in the following
            areas: (a) implementation of the Bank's Action Plan and
            additional measures identified by Management with respect to
            the affected parties (including the 2,416 families already
            relocated and the estimated 6,000 families to be relocated
            in Paraguay prior to completion of the Project); (b)
            grievance procedures for resolving claims related to the
            Project; (c) the activities o f the Inter- American
            Development Bank (IDB) in the Project, and how the IDB and
            the Bank have been collaborating on issues identified during
            the Inspection; and (d) decisions taken with respect to the
            reservoir's water level and potential impacts. This
            report is organized in seven sections. Following this
            Introduction, Section I1 provides an update on recent events
            concerning the Project. Section I11 summarizes progress to
            date on the implementation of key components of the Action
            Plan and provides further details on the measures being
            taken to address the issues that have been identified.
            Section IV summarizes progress in establishing grievance
            procedures. Section V provides an update on the
            collaboration between the Bank and IDB. Section V I provides
            an update on decisions concerning the reservoir's water
            level, and Section VI1 presents the conclusions. Annex 1
            provides a brief description of Bank loans in support of the
            Project. Annex 2 provides a more detailed presentation o f
            implementation progress on the Management Action Plan, in
            the form o f an annotated matrix. A map of the Project area
            is also attached.

repnme.cdata!:
Paraguay - Reform Project for the Water and
            Telecommunications Sectors; Argentina - SEGBA V Power
            Distribution Project : Management Report and Recommendations
            in Response to the Inspection Panel Investigation Report

abstracts.cdata!:
Four sets of claims are discussed below.
            The Panel's findings dismissed the first two of these.
            The first set of claims states that more than 4,000 families
            living in the areas directly affected by the Yacyreta
            Project at the reservoir's current operating level have
            had severe impacts. The Panel did not substantiate the
            requesters' claim that the reservoir causes constant
            flooding of urban creeks. The Panel also finds that the
            reservoir does not cause contamination of the Parana River
            and the creeks. With respect to the claims that the
            reservoir has caused the spread of diseases and severe
            health problems the Panel notes that the Yacyreta reservoir
            is not the cause of the polluted water used by the
            complainants for washing clothes and that there are
            potentially many different reasons why such skin irritations
            might occur. The second set of claims alleges that a
            proposed wastewater treatment plant, to be built in
            Encarnacion, would further pollute the environment. The
            third set of claims alleges that the families affected by
            the raising of the reservoir level were not all identified.
            The fourth set of claims alleges that the resettlement and
            income restoration programs are not being properly
            implemented. The Panels finds that the impacts of specific
            resettlement sites were not fully assessed, and that
            alternative sites for resettlement areas were not considered.

5042073.projn: AR-Yacyreta Hydroelectric & Segba V -- P005968,PY-Asuncion Sewerage -- P007926
5042073.sectr: Water, sanitation and flood protection,Energy and mining

repnme.cdata!:
Argentina - Fifth Power Project (SEGBA V),
            and Paraguay - Water and Telecommunications Sectors Reform
            Project : Inspection Panel Investigation Report

abstracts.cdata!:
The Yacyreta Hydroelectric Project is a
            joint venture between Argentina and Paraguay, who concluded
            a treaty for the Yacyreta Hydroelectric Dam, a joint
            undertaking, managed by a semi-autonomous bi-national
            entity. The Yacyreta Project extends more than two decades,
            and, its social and environmental parts are partly financed
            under both the Argentina, and Paraguay loans. This report
            concludes the Panel's investigation into allegations in
            the Request for Inspection submitted in May 2002. It
            adresses Bank environmental compliance issues raised by the
            complaint: the adequacy of environmental assessments, the
            relationship between the level of the reservoir and urban
            flooding, and ground water levels, the water-related health
            problems, and, the location and design of the sewage
            treatment plant. It finds the environmental screening
            process was appropriate. However, on reviewing the
            environmental assessments and resettlement plans, it was
            found these to be very inadequate, not in compliance with
            the Bank's Operational Directive OD 4.01. It considers
            the biophysical environment, and urban and peri-urban
            environments, finding that both environmental and social
            assessments should have anticipated the induced effects
            associated with the Project, that construction of the
            Yacyreta dam has a negligible effect on the water level of
            the Parana river at Encarnacion, especially in times of
            flood, that the reservoir is frequently operated under
            excessive water production levels, and that this is not
            consistent with neither the loan agreement, nor the Third
            Owners Agreement, as amended. Moreover, the Panel confirms
            that flooding makes the drinking water unsafe, however, it
            finds that the alleged causal relationship between the level
            of the Yacyreta reservoir, and pollution of wells and
            flooding of latrines is not correct, while the existence of
            the monitoring program was verified, reviewed, and no
            evidence contradicting the findings was found, and, confirms
            that the Ministry of Health and Social Welfare of Paraguay
            adequately monitors the incidence of both disease, and
            disease vectors. Importantly, the Panel finds that
            responsibility for the cost of connection to the sewer
            system may become a significant source of conflict, and
            needs urgent attention of Bank Management. The Panel finds
            persuasive evidence of erroneous omissions on the number of
            people present at the 1990 census, thus making them
            ineligible for Project compensation and resettlement
            benefits, and, that this sole basis for restoration of
            income does not satisfy OD 4.30's requirement for many
            affected people, and, that grievance mechanisms were neither
            in compliance with the directive.

            carry out proper supervision and monitoring of the work.
            This led to nothing more than the dismantling of productive
            systems; community structures and social connections were
            weakened and families were dispersed.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Eligibility Report for
            Paraguay's SEGBA V Power Distribution Project describes
            the project and Request for Inspection. The Request was
            submitted by Federacion de Afectados por Yacyreta de Itapua
            y Misiones (FEDAYIM), a local nongovernmental organization
            on its behalf as well as of more than 4,000 families who
            believe their lives are being affected socially and
            environmentally, because of the impacts of the Yacyreta
            Hydroelectric Dam. According to the Request, these families
            were not appropriately identified and "quantified in
            their real dimensions" as a consequence, thousands of
            them were excluded from existing compensation and mitigation
            programs in spite of the fact that they have owned and
            occupied lands affected by the construction of the dam for
            more than 20 years. The Eligibility Report examines the
            Request and the Management's Response and finds that
            the Requesters have a righteous claim that the Bank is in
            violation of its policies and procedures.  The Panel
            concludes that the eligibility requirements for an
            Investigation have been met.

abstracts.cdata!:
This Request for Inspection was filed by
            The Federation of Persons Affected by Yacyreta in Itapua and
            Misiones (Federaci�n de Afectados por Yacyreta de Itapua y
            Misiones - FEDAYIM), to examine the effects flooding has had
            on numerous families that were relocated on the banks of the
            Potiy River in Paraguay. The Request cites that the building
            of the dam on the Parana River also caused the healthy
            drinking water to be polluted and that the building of
            housing settlements along the river also caused more
            pollution of drinking water. A waste management plant that
            was planned will not benefit the neighborhoods along the
            river and the group believes that pollution will be
            irreparable. The stagnant water in the reservoir behind the
            dam also causes concern because of microorganisms and the
            harboring of diseases.  The response submits that the area
            flooded had been a floodplain and was usually flooded before
            the implementation of the dam.  As a result of a large
            passage of time between the raising of the reservoir water
            and the resettlement of communities, new groups of people
            entered the area and settled in areas that were to be
            resettled.  The Management believes that the obligations
            concerning the project have been carried out and an
            Inspection Panel investigation is not warranted.
